# Quarterback U

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

**Quarterback U** is a nickname used by
[sportswriters](/wiki/Sports_journalist "Sports journalist") to refer to
colleges that have trained a series of notable football
[quarterbacks](/wiki/Quarterback "Quarterback") (QBs). It is a literary device
invoked in the individual discretion of sportswriters and does not represent
any formal decision-making process or organized sportswriters' poll. Generally
speaking, the term implies that many of the school's former quarterbacks later
had successful careers in professional football, particularly in the [National
Football League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League")
(NFL).

A _Wall Street Journal_ article on November 18, 2012, pointed out that 'Purdue
may be the ultimate Quarterback U. Since the 1970 merger (between the AFL and
NFL), quarterbacks from Purdue have started 724 NFL games, easily the most of
any major-conference program.' After Purdue QBs' 724 NFL games, the next best
schools were the University of Washington (623 starts), Miami (573),
University of Southern California (547) and Notre Dame (543).[1]

In August 2009, an _[Altoona Mirror](/wiki/Altoona_Mirror "Altoona Mirror")_
writer sought to name "Quarterback U" by player achievements, such as NFL
starts, Pro Bowl appearances, and Heisman Trophies won. He noted that, in the
Super Bowl era, [USC](/wiki/USC_Trojans_football "USC Trojans football") (15),
[Notre Dame](/wiki/Notre_Dame_Fighting_Irish_football "Notre Dame Fighting
Irish football") (13), [Washington](/wiki/Washington_Huskies_football
"Washington Huskies football") (12), [Miami](/wiki/Miami_Hurricanes_football
"Miami Hurricanes football") (10), [Stanford](/wiki/Stanford_Cardinal_football
"Stanford Cardinal football") (10), and [UCLA](/wiki/UCLA_Bruins_football
"UCLA Bruins football") (10) produced at least ten starting NFL quarterbacks,
while [Purdue](/wiki/Purdue_Boilermakers_football "Purdue Boilermakers
football") recorded the most combined NFL career starts (704). The article
concluded that no single program deserved the title significantly more than
others.[2]

## Examples[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quarterback_U&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Examples")]

### Brigham Young
University[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quarterback_U&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Brigham Young University")]

Sports writers dubbed the [BYU](/wiki/BYU_Cougars_football "BYU Cougars
football") as a Quarterback U from the mid-1980s through the 1990s,[3] during
which time it produced [Jim McMahon](/wiki/Jim_McMahon "Jim McMahon"), [Steve
Young](/wiki/Steve_Young_\(American_football\) "Steve Young \(American
football\)"), [Gifford Nielsen](/wiki/Gifford_Nielsen "Gifford Nielsen"),
[Robbie Bosco](/wiki/Robbie_Bosco "Robbie Bosco") and [Ty
Detmer](/wiki/Ty_Detmer "Ty Detmer"). The _[Deseret News](/wiki/Deseret_News
"Deseret News")_ wrote that the last great BYU signal caller was 2001 [Heisman
Trophy](/wiki/Heisman_Trophy "Heisman Trophy") runner-up [Brandon
Doman](/wiki/Brandon_Doman "Brandon Doman"), who also later served as the
Cougars' [offensive coordinator](/wiki/Offensive_coordinator "Offensive
coordinator"). It also asserted that, upon Doman's graduation, head coach
[Gary Crowton](/wiki/Gary_Crowton "Gary Crowton") rotated quarterbacks so
frequently that it adversely affected their performance.[4][5]

### Purdue
University[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quarterback_U&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Purdue University")]

In the 1960s, [Purdue](/wiki/Purdue "Purdue") became known as 'Quarterback U'
and 'Cradle of Quarterbacks' by media and rivals such as [Ohio
State](/wiki/Ohio_State "Ohio State") and [Notre
Dame](/wiki/University_of_Notre_Dame "University of Notre Dame") due to its
prominent QBs. Between 1967 and 1974, Purdue QBs [Len Dawson](/wiki/Len_Dawson
"Len Dawson") and [Bob Griese](/wiki/Bob_Griese "Bob Griese") started five
[Super Bowls](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl"), winning three; [Cecil
Isbell](/wiki/Cecil_Isbell "Cecil Isbell") led the [Green Bay
Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay Packers") to a NFL title in 1939,
[Elmer Oliphant](/wiki/Elmer_Oliphant "Elmer Oliphant") led the [Buffalo All-
Americans](/wiki/Buffalo_All-Americans "Buffalo All-Americans") to a disputed
NFL title in 1921; Purdue has produced NFL starting QBs in [Mike
Phipps](/wiki/Mike_Phipps "Mike Phipps"), [Gary
Danielson](/wiki/Gary_Danielson "Gary Danielson"), [Jim
Everett](/wiki/Jim_Everett "Jim Everett"), [Mark Hermann](/wiki/Mark_Hermann
"Mark Hermann"), and [Kyle Orton](/wiki/Kyle_Orton "Kyle Orton"); [Scott
Campbell](/wiki/Scott_Campbell_\(American_football\) "Scott Campbell
\(American football\)") and [Curtis Painter](/wiki/Curtis_Painter "Curtis
Painter") were well-known backup quarterbacks, [Joey
Elliott](/wiki/Joey_Elliott "Joey Elliott") is a starting QB in the [Canadian
Football League](/wiki/Canadian_Football_League "Canadian Football League").
The tradition has continued through to this day with [Drew
Brees](/wiki/Drew_Brees "Drew Brees") winning the [Super Bowl
XLIV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLIV "Super Bowl XLIV"), in which he was also named
[MVP](/wiki/Super_Bowl_Most_Valuable_Player_Award "Super Bowl Most Valuable
Player Award").[6][7][8][9][10][11] 15 Purdue QBs went on to the NFL; Purdue
is tied for first with Alabama in producing Super Bowl winning
quarterbacks.[12][13] According to ESPN.com, Purdue QBs have won (and
started)[14] more NFL games than any other school; thrown for the most
touchdowns and yards in the NFL. Purdue QBs have won more League TD titles (14
through the 2012 NFL season) than any other school.

### Stanford
University[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quarterback_U&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Stanford University")]

As early as 1975, the term Quarterback U had been applied to [Stanford
University](/wiki/Stanford_Cardinal_football "Stanford Cardinal football"),
which had produced such players as [Frankie Albert](/wiki/Frankie_Albert
"Frankie Albert"), [John Brodie](/wiki/John_Brodie "John Brodie"), [Jim
Plunkett](/wiki/Jim_Plunkett "Jim Plunkett"), [Don Bunce](/wiki/Don_Bunce "Don
Bunce"), and [Mike Boryla](/wiki/Mike_Boryla "Mike Boryla").[15] This
reputation was enhanced when [Bill
Walsh](/wiki/Bill_Walsh_\(American_football_coach\) "Bill Walsh \(American
football coach\)") joined the Cardinal as head coach, and quarterbacks [Guy
Benjamin](/wiki/Guy_Benjamin "Guy Benjamin"), [Steve Dils](/wiki/Steve_Dils
"Steve Dils"), and [Turk Schonert](/wiki/Turk_Schonert "Turk Schonert")
promptly led the NCAA in passing in 1977, 1978, and 1979.[16] They were
followed by perhaps Stanford's best-known quarterback, [John
Elway](/wiki/John_Elway "John Elway"), who played at the university from 1979
to 1982, finishing second in the Heisman voting his senior season.[17] Elway
would go on to have a Hall of Fame career with the Broncos and win the Super
Bowl in 1997 and 1998.[18] By 1989, the _[San Jose Mercury
News](/wiki/San_Jose_Mercury_News "San Jose Mercury News")_ surmised that
Stanford's "once bright legacy" as Quarterback U appeared "to be flickering
out".[19] However, recently Stanford's quarterback tradition has experienced
something of a revival under [Andrew Luck](/wiki/Andrew_Luck "Andrew Luck").
[Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck") finished second in the voting for the Heisman
trophy, the award given to college football's most outstanding player, in both
2010 and 2011.[20] When drafted by the Indianapolis Colts in the [2012 NFL
Draft](/wiki/2012_NFL_Draft "2012 NFL Draft"), he became the fourth Stanford
quarterback taken with the first overall pick, following Elway, Plunkett and
[Bobby Garrett](/wiki/Bobby_Garrett "Bobby Garrett"),[21] but the first since
Elway was taken by the Colts in 1983. Stanford quarterbacks have started 7
Super Bowls, winning 4, and garnering two [Super Bowl Most Valuable Player
Awards](/wiki/Super_Bowl_Most_Valuable_Player_Award "Super Bowl Most Valuable
Player Award").

### Texas Tech
University[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quarterback_U&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Texas Tech University")]

In 2005, a _[Sporting News](/wiki/Sporting_News "Sporting News")_ writer
described [Texas Tech](/wiki/Texas_Tech_Red_Raiders_football "Texas Tech Red
Raiders football") as Quarterback U in an article that bestowed several
positional "U" monikers with the criteria being college performance since
2000. Its author cited head coach [Mike
Leach](/wiki/Mike_Leach_\(American_football_coach\) "Mike Leach \(American
football coach\)")'s numerous 4,000-yard-plus passers.[22]

### University of
Maryland[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quarterback_U&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: University of Maryland")]

During the 1980s, the term was also applied to
[Maryland](/wiki/Maryland_Terrapins_football "Maryland Terrapins football"),
which produced several NFL-caliber quarterbacks during the tenures of head
coach [Bobby Ross](/wiki/Bobby_Ross "Bobby Ross") and offensive coordinator
and quarterbacks/receivers coach [Joe Krivak](/wiki/Joe_Krivak "Joe Krivak").
These [Maryland quarterbacks](/wiki/Maryland_Terrapins_quarterbacks "Maryland
Terrapins quarterbacks") included [Boomer Esiason](/wiki/Boomer_Esiason
"Boomer Esiason"), [Frank Reich](/wiki/Frank_Reich "Frank Reich"), [Neil
O'Donnell](/wiki/Neil_O%27Donnell "Neil O'Donnell"), [Scott
Zolak](/wiki/Scott_Zolak "Scott Zolak"), and [Stan
Gelbaugh](/wiki/Stan_Gelbaugh "Stan Gelbaugh").[23][24][25] In 2005, _[The
Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")_ reapplied
the label to the Terrapins under head coach [Ralph
Friedgen](/wiki/Ralph_Friedgen "Ralph Friedgen") and offensive coordinator
[Charlie Taaffe](/wiki/Charlie_Taaffe "Charlie Taaffe"), after [Sam
Hollenbach](/wiki/Sam_Hollenbach "Sam Hollenbach") became the [Atlantic Coast
Conference](/wiki/Atlantic_Coast_Conference "Atlantic Coast Conference")'s
leading passer. That coaching staff also groomed [Shaun Hill](/wiki/Shaun_Hill
"Shaun Hill") and [Scott McBrien](/wiki/Scott_McBrien "Scott McBrien").[26]

### University of
Miami[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quarterback_U&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: University of Miami")]

In the 1980s, the term was often applied to the [University of
Miami](/wiki/Miami_Hurricanes_football "Miami Hurricanes football").[27] In
2003, Tracy Gale, a sport publicist working for the University of Miami, named
[Fran Curci](/wiki/Fran_Curci "Fran Curci"), who was Miami's quarterback in
1959, as the start of what he called "Miami's Quarterback U tradition."[28]
[George Mira](/wiki/George_Mira "George Mira"), [Jim Kelly](/wiki/Jim_Kelly
"Jim Kelly"), [Bernie Kosar](/wiki/Bernie_Kosar "Bernie Kosar"), [Vinny
Testaverde](/wiki/Vinny_Testaverde "Vinny Testaverde"), [Steve
Walsh](/wiki/Steve_Walsh_\(American_football\) "Steve Walsh \(American
football\)"), [Ken Dorsey](/wiki/Ken_Dorsey "Ken Dorsey"), [Craig
Erickson](/wiki/Craig_Erickson "Craig Erickson"), and [Gino
Torretta](/wiki/Gino_Torretta "Gino Torretta") are some Hurricanes
quarterbacks that influenced his use of the term.[29][30] The term is still
often applied, although Miami currently has fewer quarterbacks starting in the
NFL than it has in the past. In 2008, all three Miami quarterbacks entered the
season with no game experience, and pundits charged head coach [Randy
Shannon](/wiki/Randy_Shannon "Randy Shannon") with rebuilding the program's
reputation of producing high-quality signalcallers.[31][32][33]

### University of
Michigan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quarterback_U&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: University of Michigan")]

In recent years, sportswriters have mentioned several schools as being
appropriate for the designation. A 2005 [ESPN](/wiki/ESPN "ESPN") article
cited that, since 1988, [Michigan](/wiki/Michigan_Wolverines_football
"Michigan Wolverines football") sent as many starting quarterbacks to the NFL
as the University of Miami. It argued that "three yards and a cloud of dust"
is no longer the offensive philosophy at Michigan.[34] A year later,
[Rivals.com](/wiki/Rivals.com "Rivals.com") proclaimed that Michigan was "the
new Quarterback U."[35][36] [Elvis Grbac](/wiki/Elvis_Grbac "Elvis Grbac"),
[Todd Collins](/wiki/Todd_Collins_\(quarterback\) "Todd Collins
\(quarterback\)"), [Tom Brady](/wiki/Tom_Brady "Tom Brady"), [Jim
Harbaugh](/wiki/Jim_Harbaugh "Jim Harbaugh"), [Brian
Griese](/wiki/Brian_Griese "Brian Griese") and [Chad Henne](/wiki/Chad_Henne
"Chad Henne") are some of the Wolverine quarterbacks who have gone on to start
in the NFL.[34]

### University of Southern
California[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quarterback_U&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: University of Southern California")]

After the 2008 season, _[The Los Angeles Times](/wiki/The_Los_Angeles_Times
"The Los Angeles Times")_ claimed that [USC](/wiki/USC_Trojans_football "USC
Trojans football"), more traditionally known as "Tailback U", was the school
most deserving of the designation.[37][38] In 2009, 4 former USC quarterbacks
started in an NFL game: [Matt Leinart](/wiki/Matt_Leinart "Matt Leinart"),
[Matt Cassell](/wiki/Matt_Cassell "Matt Cassell"), [Carson
Palmer](/wiki/Carson_Palmer "Carson Palmer"), and [Mark
Sanchez](/wiki/Mark_Sanchez "Mark Sanchez").

### University of
Washington[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Quarterback_U&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: University of Washington")]

[Washington](/wiki/Washington_Huskies_football "Washington Huskies football")
quarterbacks have consistently advanced to the NFL, with [16 of the previous
18 starting
quarterbacks](/wiki/List_of_Washington_Huskies_starting_quarterbacks "List of
Washington Huskies starting quarterbacks") as of 2012 having started in the
NFL.[39][40] Washington's [Pro Football Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame "Pro Football Hall of Fame") member
[Warren Moon](/wiki/Warren_Moon "Warren Moon") is [fourth in all-time passing
yardage](/wiki/List_of_gridiron_football_quarterbacks_passing_statistics "List
of gridiron football quarterbacks passing statistics"), reflecting his CFL and
NFL careers. Other notable alumni include [Chris
Chandler](/wiki/Chris_Chandler "Chris Chandler"), [Mark
Brunell](/wiki/Mark_Brunell "Mark Brunell"), [Damon Huard](/wiki/Damon_Huard
"Damon Huard") and [Jake Locker](/wiki/Jake_Locker "Jake Locker"). ESPN points
to the program's history by the early 1980s.[41]
